subject: Sexual Health
title: Sleep Shifts in Puberty
description: A quick win: understand Sleep Shifts in Puberty.

hook.text: Teens are not lazy for wanting to sleep late. Puberty physically shifts their internal clock by about two hours.

buildup.text: Melatonin release shifts later during puberty, making teens unable to fall asleep before 11 PM or midnight.

discovery.text: Teens need 8 to 10 hours of sleep, but early school start times force them awake during their deepest sleep.

twist.text: Schools that delayed start times saw improved grades, fewer car accidents, and better mental health in students.

climax.text: Recognizing the biology of teen sleep can reshape school policies and improve adolescent well-being.

punchline.text: Not lazy. Biologically wired to sleep later.

quiz.question: What happens to melatonin release during puberty?
options: It shifts to later in the evening
